abstract.text: A voice channel that allows players to speak with each other in a multiplayer game.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: GameKit provides the underlying mechanism to implement voice chat between players in a multiplayer game. It’s your responsibility to provide player controls and display feedback during the chat.
First, configure voice chat by adding the
key to the Information Property List and creating an audio session. Then, create a
method passing a string that identifies the voice channel. Use the
method to connect players to the channel. Use the
property to activate the microphone or switch the microphone between channels.
property to update the interface when a player connects, speaks, or disconnects from a chat. You can also add controls that mute and set the volume using the
Note that if there’s insufficient bandwidth over Wi-Fi to maintain a voice chat, GameKit may disconnect players from the channel or disband a channel.

abstract.text: A message that tells the user why the app is requesting access to the device’s microphone.
Enable players to interact with friends, compare leaderboard ranks, earn achievements, and participate in multiplayer games.
An
object provides a standard user interface to display achievement progress for the local player. If the
class is available, you should use it instead.
The
class is used to respond to events related to challenges sent or received by the local player.
The object representing the currently signed-in iCloud user.
Your game uses the
class to present a screen that allows the local player to send friend requests to other players.
The dashboard that allows players to access their Game Center data in your game.
A game session you can use to save game data, invite other players, and create turn-based and real-time game apps.
A user interface you can use to invite other users into a tvOS game session.
The
class provides a standard user interface that displays leaderboard scores to the player. If the
class is available, you should use it instead.
Joins the local player to a voice channel.
Begins a SharePlay activity for your game when a FaceTime call is active.
Provides a standard user interface to allow one iOS device to discover and connect to another.
An object containing information for a score that was earned by the player.
A
object provides the ability to discover and connect to nearby iOS devices using Bluetooth or Wi-fi.
The
class is used to respond to important messages related to turn-based matches. To use it, call the
class method to get the singleton instance and assign an object that implements the
protocol to its
property. All methods are called on the main thread.
The delegate for the event handler.
Returns the shared instance of the event handler.
The
protocol is implemented by an object to receive notifications events for turn-based matches. All methods are called on the main thread.
A voice channel that allows players to speak with each other in a multiplayer game.
The state of a player in a voice chat.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the channel is sampling the microphone.
Returns whether voice chat is available on the device.
The name of the voice chat channel.
An array of strings containing the player identifiers for the players connected to the channel.
Handles when a player in the chat changes state.
A method that handles when a player’s voice chat changes state.
The players connected to the channel.
Mutes a player in a voice chat.
Mutes a player in the chat, including the local player.
Starts communication with other players in a channel.
Ends communication with other players in a channel.
The volume level for the channel.
The
class allows your application to connect two iOS devices into a voice chat.
Enable players to voice chat with all, or groups of, players in a multiplayer game.

Enable the local player to choose other players

abstract.text: The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
